stream_context.summary: Kaze builds out Course 13’s boss area and brainstorms the full boss fight concept for “Raphael the Raven,” while also importing and manually looping an Ice Dungeon streamed track. He discusses camera control UX changes, Fast64 fog/material issues that affect N64 visuals, and reiterates his philosophy that Mario 64’s core appeal is freedom rather than forced difficulty or heavy direction.
stream_context.significance_reason: By the end of the stream Kaze commits to a concrete multi-phase Raphael the Raven boss fight concept (tower intro → anti-gravity/star-dodge transition → moon arena fight with throwable ‘cheese’ projectiles) and identifies the key technical blocker: implementing/borrowing planetary gravity for the rotating moon set-piece.

findings.summary: Course 13 is focused on the Raphael the Raven boss encounter; Kaze’s priority for bosses is creating a memorable set-piece first, then building mechanics that support that spectacle.
findings.quote: For bosses, it being a cool set-piece is my number one priority, always.

findings.summary: Kaze wants the intro beat to be Raphael visually ‘blocking’ the moon (moon darkens/disappears, then eyes appear), to create an immediate “oh shit” moment before gameplay begins.

He rejects simply recreating Yoshi’s Island’s original Raphael fight 1:1, worrying it would feel like a “cheap callback,” and also notes the visual/gameplay mismatch of a 3D moon fight where you can’t easily read the far side.

The working boss concept: start on a tower; Raphael stomps/initiates anti-gravity so Mario ‘falls upward’ into a star-dodging sequence; Mario then lands on a moon arena where Raphael ground-pounds to send multiple projectiles around the moon; where projectiles collide, a pickup spawns that Mario can throw to damage Raphael; repeat with star-dodge transitions between hits.

Kaze lands on a clear interaction affordance: frozen ‘cheese ninja stars’ collide and break/transform into a sparkling unfrozen cheese pickup, signaling it’s now throwable and used to damage the boss.

He adds narrative framing to the arena: a nest on the tower with an egg; on victory, the egg breaks and yields the reward star, implying Raphael is ‘protecting’/hoarding the egg as the motivation for the fight.

The moon concept likely requires planetary gravity or a similar system; Kaze wants this implemented at an actor/boss level if possible (to avoid risky global engine changes), but acknowledges moon programming will be difficult and plans to request existing planetary gravity code from “Arthur.”

Kaze describes a Fast64 export/graphics bug: in a single large display list with materials that mix fog and no-fog (especially with material bleeding), fog sometimes fails to turn off, causing levels (he cites Course 12 on real N64) to look “bugged” compared to livestream emulation.

Camera-control UX decision: Kaze removed a “snap” behavior because many players use a GameCube controller C-stick; accidental up/down inputs were too common, so he changed behavior to reduce unintended camera moves (and now prefers it).

Audio pipeline details: most of the OST uses an N64 MIDI-like format (M64 via SaC64), but ~20% uses large streamed audio in a custom/awkward format, so it must be used sparingly due to size constraints.
The project’s custom OST count is very high: Kaze reports 98 songs currently in-game, noting this is already more than Mario Odyssey’s 82.

Kaze imports an Ice Dungeon streamed track live and manually finds loop points by ear/timecode, then calculates sample-loop values (multiplying by 32) to make it loop correctly in-game; he keeps stereo by importing separate left/right channels.

Kaze pushes back strongly against feedback that ROM hacks should be “more difficult,” arguing Mario 64’s point is player freedom—players can self-select difficulty by taking riskier routes/jumps rather than forcing a single hard path.
findings.quote: The point is that you’re free. It’s all freedom.

findings.summary: Progress snapshot: Kaze states they’re around ~120 stars done, working on overworld and enemies, with roughly ~30% of enemies implemented.
Kaze avoids looking into the “giga leak,” describing it as ‘curse knowledge’ that could create trouble even from simply knowing what’s in it.
findings.quote: Even just knowing about things in the giga leak can get you in trouble. It’s like curse knowledge.

biobak.summary: Biobak previously sent Kaze a video reference for Raphael the Raven fight ideas; Kaze reacts positively (“That’s so cool”) and uses it as inspiration while brainstorming the encounter structure.

badub.summary: Kaze highlights Badub’s music as a standout contribution, explicitly praising his creativity and calling it “very, very sick.”
badub.quote: Badub’s music is great. The creativity he brings to the table is very, very sick.

zeina.summary: Kaze references parenting logistics: Zeina has more work than he does with the newborn, and he jokes he can’t feed the baby because he can’t breastfeed.
Zeina challenges Kaze’s approach to audio import/mixing (suggesting simpler one-shot/mono-type handling), while Kaze insists on preserving stereo for all tracks because mono “would sound so ass.”

findings.summary: Lilaa actively troubleshoots with Kaze on fog/material state issues; Kaze clarifies the bug occurs when fogged and non-fogged materials share a single large display list and fog state fails to reset.

During boss brainstorming, ZeroVolt proposes an idea Kaze calls “perfect,” which helps validate the timing/structure of the star-meeting / spawn-and-throw damage loop (exact phrasing unclear but Kaze treats it as a key confirmation).
Kaze plans to ask Arthur for existing planetary gravity code to support the rotating moon/low-gravity boss set-piece, implying Arthur has already solved this problem elsewhere.

key_stories.title: Locking in the Raphael the Raven boss concept
key_stories.summary: Kaze starts the stream with only a theme (Raphael, moon, ice castle) and a need for an attack pattern. Through chat-driven brainstorming, he converges on a multi-phase spectacle-focused fight that uses a tower intro, an anti-gravity ‘fall into stars’ dodge sequence, and a moon arena damage loop.
key_stories.challenge: How to design a boss that feels original (not a cheap Yoshi’s Island callback), readable in 3D, and mechanically fun while delivering a strong moon set-piece.
key_stories.process: He explores multiple concepts: hollow moon inside/outside gravity flipping, ice vs black Raphael variants, wall-walking/figure-8 attacks, and Galaxy-like projectile patterns. He rejects ideas requiring risky global gravity changes and instead proposes an actor-friendly structure with clear player affordances (projectiles collide → pickup spawns → throw to damage).
key_stories.outcome: A concrete plan emerges: frozen cheese projectiles collide and become a sparkling pickup; each successful hit triggers a star-dodge transition, repeating until defeat. Kaze ends by outlining next steps: build the moon, intro cutscene, and implement gravity behavior.
key_stories.key_quote: For bosses, it being a cool set-piece is my number one priority, always.

key_stories.title: The technical blocker: planetary gravity for the moon
key_stories.summary: As soon as the moon arena becomes central to the boss concept, Kaze identifies gravity as the main implementation risk. He wants to avoid engine-wide gravity changes and instead use actor-level tricks when possible.
key_stories.challenge: Make a rotating/low-gravity moon arena work in Mario 64’s engine without destabilizing global physics systems.
key_stories.process: He reasons through options (true hollow moon with inside/outside gravity vs. only outside rotation tricks) and narrows to needing a planetary-gravity-like solution. He decides to seek help from someone who has code ready.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze commits to contacting Arthur for planetary gravity code and schedules moon programming + intro cutscene work for the next stream.
key_stories.key_quote: I’m going to ask Arthur for his planetary gravity code because he already knows what to do, I think.

key_stories.title: Fixing a streamed music loop by hand
key_stories.summary: Kaze imports the Ice Dungeon streamed track and discovers it doesn’t loop as desired. He manually scrubs the waveform/timestamps to find the repeat point, computes loop values, and tests the result in-game.
key_stories.challenge: Streamed audio is large and finicky; loop points must be precise to avoid audible seams in-game.
key_stories.process: He identifies matching beats visually/aurally, sets a loop start timecode, computes the loop in samples (multiplying by 32), and re-imports while keeping stereo by splitting left/right channels.
key_stories.outcome: The track loops in-game, and Kaze adds it to the project’s streamed audio slots.

key_stories.title: A graphics pipeline pitfall: fog state not resetting
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains why a level can look correct in Blender but wrong on real N64 due to a Fast64/material export edge case. The issue appears when mixing fogged and non-fogged materials in one large display list, especially with material bleeding.
key_stories.challenge: Maintain consistent visual output across Blender, emulator, and real N64 hardware when fog is involved.
key_stories.process: He describes the reproduction conditions and clarifies it’s not world-default fog settings but state changes failing in the display list. He attributes it to a Fast64 bug/edge case.
key_stories.outcome: No final fix shown this stream, but he documents the constraint and explains why Course 12 appears “bugged” on N64.

key_stories.title: Design stance against forced difficulty in Mario 64 hacks
key_stories.summary: Kaze responds to the recurring idea that hacks need to be harder to be worthwhile. He demonstrates in vanilla Whomp’s Fortress how player-chosen risky jumps create optional difficulty without forcing it on everyone.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing player expectations for ‘challenge’ with Kaze’s goal of exploration and freedom-driven gameplay.
key_stories.process: He argues that locking progress behind difficult jumps misunderstands Mario 64’s strengths. He frames difficulty as emergent from player agency and route choice rather than mandatory gauntlets.
key_stories.outcome: A clear guiding principle for RTY: preserve freedom and allow players to opt into risk, rather than designing around constant enforced difficulty.
key_stories.key_quote: The point is that you’re free. It’s all freedom.

open_questions.topic: Planetary gravity implementation for the moon fight
open_questions.context: Kaze says moon programming will be “awful” and plans to ask Arthur for planetary gravity code; he also wants to avoid global gravity changes if possible.
questions: What existing project or prototype does Arthur’s planetary gravity code come from, and how battle-tested is it on real N64?
Will the moon use true spherical gravity, a rotated ‘local down’ trick, or segmented collision/warp zones?
What performance/memory constraints will this impose (collision complexity, camera, culling)?
How will the camera behave during the anti-gravity ‘fall into stars’ set-piece to keep players oriented?

open_questions.topic: Final decision on Raphael’s visual variant (black vs ice)
open_questions.context: Kaze likes the ice raven aesthetic because the castle already uses ice ravens, but the moon-blocking intro (moon darkens, eyes appear) seems to demand a black silhouette version.
questions: Which version is canon for RTY: ice Raphael, black silhouette Raphael, or a transformation between phases?
How much of the decision is gameplay readability vs thematic consistency with the ice castle?
What does the final intro cutscene storyboard look like shot-by-shot?

open_questions.topic: Damage loop specifics and player clarity
open_questions.context: The current plan: Raphael ground-pounds, projectiles travel around the moon, collide, and spawn a throwable pickup (unfrozen cheese) used to damage him; after a hit, Mario returns to the star-dodge sequence.
questions: How will players learn the ‘collision point → pickup → throw’ rule without explicit UI text?
What prevents degenerate strategies (camping the spawn point, stun-locking, or missing the pickup)?
How many hits/phases will the fight have, and how do later phases escalate beyond ‘more projectiles’?

open_questions.context: Kaze wants Mario to ‘fall’ into/through stars as a repeated transition and cool visual between damage phases.
questions: Is the star-dodge section a separate sub-area/warp, or simulated in-place with camera/skybox tricks?
How will collisions and player control feel (full air control vs constrained drift)?
How do you avoid motion sickness or disorientation when flipping the camera 180 degrees?

open_questions.context: Kaze proposes a nest on the tower and an egg that breaks into the reward star; he debates whether the egg should be a Yoshi egg (captured) or a raven egg.
questions: Which egg is it and what does that imply about Raphael’s motive in RTY’s story?
Is the egg purely cosmetic set-dressing, or does it factor into mechanics (hazards, phase triggers, weak point)?
How will the ‘egg explodes into a star’ moment be staged and animated?

open_questions.topic: Course 13 scope and how it ties to the broader game progression
open_questions.context: Kaze says he’s on Course 13 and building the boss arena; he also mentions overall progress (~120 stars, overworld + enemies) but not how Course 13 fits into the macro structure.
questions: Where does Course 13 sit in the game’s difficulty curve and story beats?
What is the player’s objective path leading up to Raphael—what do they learn in the level that prepares them for the boss mechanics?
Is Raphael a ‘world boss’ gate, a star/coin unlock, or optional?

open_questions.context: Kaze says he’s still thinking of releasing a demo that is “just course one.”
questions: What needs to be finished for a Course 1 demo to feel representative (UI, save system, polish, performance on hardware)?
Is the demo intended as a public milestone, a playtest tool, or a promotional beat?
What content would be intentionally held back to avoid spoilers or misrepresenting final quality?

open_questions.context: Kaze altered camera snap behavior to reduce accidental inputs for GameCube C-stick users; chat asks about analog camera options despite only one stick on N64-style controls.
questions: What is the final camera control scheme you’re aiming for across controller types (N64, GC, modern pads)?
Will there be configurable camera sensitivity/acceleration or alternate mappings (e.g., D-pad vs C-buttons)?
How do you test camera UX—do you have playtesters using different controllers?

open_questions.topic: Streamed audio constraints and selection criteria
open_questions.context: Kaze says ~20% of the OST is streamed because it’s large; he manually loops tracks and insists on stereo.
questions: What decides whether a track is M64 (SaC64) vs streamed—instrument complexity, effects, fidelity, or composer intent?
How close are you to the ROM size/memory ceiling, and what tradeoffs have you had to make to keep streamed tracks?
What tooling could reduce manual loop-point work (or is hand-tuning part of the quality bar)?

open_questions.context: Kaze says ~30% of enemies are implemented but doesn’t detail the pipeline from concept → model/animation → behaviors → integration.
questions: What is the enemy creation pipeline and which steps are the bottleneck (animation, AI, collision, effects, testing)?
How do you decide whether an enemy is worth the implementation cost vs using variants of existing ones?
Who on the team (or community) contributes to enemies, and how do you coordinate iteration/feedback?
